isis.stitle: DIAMONDLIFE™ (BOSCH PIN SLIDE) DISC BRAKES For Vehicles Built After June 2, 2002 - install - ROTOR AND WHEEL HUB ASSEMBLY

svcsubproc.title: Install

step1.para:
Install front rotor onto wheel hub (Items 12 and 8, Figure 30)
and (Items 12 and 8, Figure 31)
by installing retaining nuts and washers (Item 14, Figure 30)
or retaining bolts, washers and nut (Item 13, Figure 31)
securing them together. Refer to TORQUE CHART
for proper tightening specifications.

Install rear rotor onto wheel hub (Items 11 and 7, Figure 32)
and (Items 11 and 7, Figure 33)
by installing retaining nuts (Item 12, Figure 32)
or retaining bolts, washers and nuts (Item 12, Figure 33)
securing them together. Refer to TORQUE CHART
for proper tightening specifications.

On front axles, for installation of rotor and wheel hub assembly (Items 12 and 8, Figure 30)
and (Items 12 and 8, Figure 31) , refer to GROUP 02 - FRONT AXLE in the Master Service Manual for proper rotor and wheel hub assembly installation along with bearings and related components.

On rear axles, for installation of rotor and wheel hub assembly (Items 11 and 7, Figure 32)
and (Items 11 and 7, Figure 33) , refer to GROUP 14 - REAR AXLE in the Master Service Manual for proper rotor and wheel hub assembly installation along with bearings and related components.

Before proceeding to next step, adjust wheel bearings. Refer to ADJUSTMENTS
, WHEEL BEARING ADJUSTMENT for proper procedures.

svcsubproc.para:
Refer to Figure 75
for Items in parentheses unless otherwise noted.

step1.para:
Before installing caliper, visually inspect anchor plate (Item 1) for damage or defects to mating surfaces at anchor plate pad abutment slippers (Item 2), anchor plate tie bar (Item 3), if so equipped (73 mm brakes only) and check guide pin heads (Item 4). If the anchor plate pad abutment slippers or guide pins are damaged or defective they must be replaced. If the anchor plate pad abutment slippers or guide pins are being replaced, refer to ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Disassemble
, ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Clean and Inspect
and ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Assemble
to disassemble, clean and inspect and assemble anchor plate pad abutment slippers and guide pins.

If guide pins (Figure 67)
are being replaced. Pull guide pin boots (Item 5) off anchor plate (Item 1) or guide pins (Item 4) and check for damage or defects. If damage or defects are found, they must be replaced. If guide pin boots are not damaged or defective, wash them in soapy water and dry them. Once again, after the guide pin boots have been cleaned and dried, inspect them for damage or defects. If damage or defects are found, they must be replaced. Refer to ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Disassemble
, ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Clean and Inspect
and ANCHOR PLATE AND SPLASH SHIELD, Assemble
to disassemble, clean and inspect and assemble guide pin boots.

figure.caption: Figure 75. Inspect Anchor Plate for Damage or Defects

svcsubproc.para: Refer to Figure 76 for Items in parentheses.

step1.para: If old disc brake pads are being reinstalled, position inboard and outboard disc brake pads (Items 1 and 2) on front brakes and (Items 3 and 4) on rear brakes, onto anchor plate pad abutment slippers (Item 5) with the lining facing toward the rotor (Item 6), driver side front and rear brake shown. Using markings made during removal be sure to install disc brake pad back on the same wheel it was removed from and also in the same inboard and outboard location.

figure.caption: Figure 76. Install Inboard and Outboard Disc Brake Pads

caution.para:
The HX-7A1-EE inboard and outboard disc brake pads (Items 1 and 2, Figure 77) are not interchangeable. The word "FORWARD" and the "ARROW" markings on the brake pads backing plate show forward rotation direction of the rotor (Item 4, Figure 77). The arrow MUST point in the forward rotor rotation direction (Figure 78). The optional HX-402-EE and SOFTER lining brake pads inboard and outboard disc brake pads (Item 4, Figure 59)
are interchangeable between the inner and outer locations.

figure.caption: Figure 77. Inboard and Outboard Disc Brake Pads Marking of Arrow and Forward

calloutgroup.callout1: DRIVER SIDE REAR BRAKE PADS (73 mm) SHOWN

figure.caption: Figure 78. Install Inboard and Outboard Disc Brake Pads (HX-7A1-EE with Arrow in Forward Rotor Rotation Direction)

step1.para:
Carefully rotate the caliper (Item 1, Figure 79) closed about the lower (bottom) hex flanged mounting bolt and guide pin (Items 2 and 3, Figure 79). Refer to DISC BRAKE PADS, Install
.

figure.caption: Figure 79. Rotate Caliper Closed About Lower Hex Mounting Bolt and Guide Pin

svcsubproc.para:
Refer to Figure 34
for Items in parentheses.

step1.para: Install anchor plate tie bar (Item 1), if so equipped (73 mm brake assembly only), to anchor plate (Item 2) by installing 12-point head bolts (Item 3). Tighten to 40 to 50 lbf-ft (54 to 68 N•m).

If necessary, bleed brakes, Refer to BLEEDING INSTRUCTIONS
.
Check the master cylinder reservoir and fill if necessary. Refer to GROUP 10 - LUBRICATION in the Master Service Manual for proper brake fluid.

warning.para: When adding fluids, take care to identify fluids (power steering fluid or brake fluid) and use only in the proper system. Discard all fluid bled or drained from either system. Do not use for refill, cleaning or any other purpose. Failure to observe these precautions could result in failure of the brake system, with resultant personal injury and/or property damage.

step1.para:
Install wheel (tire and rim) on vehicle and remove floor stands. Refer to GROUP 17 - WHEELS in the Master Service Manual for proper wheel installation. Refer to TORQUE CHART
for proper tightening specifications based on mounting hardware size and thread type.

note.para: When installing the wheel (tire and rim) on disc brake axles, make sure the tire valve stem clears the brake caliper. The use of a valve stem retainer or a tire manufacturer's stem forming tool are the only acceptable methods of obtaining clearance when necessary.

step1.para: After any brake service, be sure to test brakes prior to returning vehicle to service. A firm pedal should be felt during brake application.
